overview_of_class:
Classical Mythology, F17, with Jonah Radding

In this course, we will study ancient Greek mythology through a close reading of ancient texts in translation. We will move chronologically through a variety of mythical traditions, beginning with Homer and Hesiod and their pan-hellenic poems on gods and heroes, and ending with the mythology of classical Athens. Throughout, we will pay close attention to the way these myths related to their original social and historical contexts, and how they reflect or express Greek identity and ideology. As part of this process, we will also examine how myths are developed and used in the contemporary world.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: To become familiar with the major Greek mythical characters and narratives; to acquire basic knowledge of critical approaches to myth; to understand the legacy of Classical mythology in our own times, and how we ourselves use mythologies in constructing our identities and explaining the world in which we live.
